awd_titl_txt: Doctoral Dissertation Research: The evolutionary history of the human and ape knee
awd_abstract_narration:
Bipedalism, or upright walking, is a defining characteristic of modern and ancestral humans. It was one of the earliest defining traits of the human lineage and played a significant role in shaping our behavior and anatomy. To better understand the evolution of bipedalism, many researchers have studied the pelvis, foot, and vertebral column, all of which play a part in bipedal movement; somewhat less attention has been paid to the knee joint despite its essential role during human bipedalism. This doctoral dissertation research project studies the movement and anatomy of the knee joint and the results of the research can be relevant both for understanding the origins and evolution of human upright walking, as well as functional anatomy of the knee joint. Given the high frequency of knee replacement in the U.S., this offers one key example of how evolutionary understandings can potentially inform medical perspectives, and approaches to injury prevention and intervention.

The goal of this research is to investigate the relationship between knee joint anatomy and locomotor function in modern primates to help understand the pattern of locomotor behavior in hominin and hominoid fossil records. This project is carried out in three complementary phases that combine modern primate kinematic data, modern primate skeletal data, and data collected from the distal femur, proximal tibia, and patella of fossil hominins and hominoids. These phases include collection of kinematic data on gait and degree of knee extension in living primates as they walk bipedally, skeletal sample measurements in individuals of the same species from museum collections, and application of results of the first two phases to interpret anatomy in the human and ape fossil record. Ultimately the results of this research can inform paleoanthropological perspectives regarding the body form from which modern human bipedalism evolved.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Upright walking, or “bipedalism,” is one of the key traits that make humans unique, evolving in our ancestry about 7 million years ago. This adaptation strongly influenced our evolutionary history. While researchers have studied the hip, foot, and ankle to understand bipedalism, less attention has been paid to the knee joint despite its critical role in maintaining an efficient upright posture. This project (Award #2215721) focused on how the shape of the bones in the knee joint, particularly the thigh bone (femur) and shin bone (tibia), relates to how different species move. By examining these relationships, this study sheds light on how upright walking evolved.

                With funding from the NSF DDRIG, Miller traveled to museums in South Africa, Kenya, Belgium, and the U.S. to collect 3D scans of the knee bones from modern humans, fossil human ancestors, fossil apes, and 12 living primate species. In total, Miller collected 280 femur scans and 284 tibia scans. Miller also traveled to Los Angeles to record videos of primate movement.

                Using the 3D scans, Miller took linear measurements on the bones and tested hypotheses about features in the knee related to upright walking. The results, published in the journal Evolutionary Anthropology, showed some surprising similarities between modern humans and monkeys. Although humans and monkeys move very differently, their knee bones may experience similar forces because of their need for a stable joint. Fossil human ancestors showed overlap with modern human traits, but with some variation between species.

                To better understand the differences between species, Miller used a method called Diffeomorphic Shape Matching (DSM). This technique allowed her to compare the full 3D shapes of the bones across the different species. The results for the tibia (shin bone) showed a large amount of similarity among species, suggesting this bone might not be the most reliable indicator of movement patterns. However, the femur (thigh bone) showed more differences between species. By comparing the shape of the femur to the degree to which primates can bend their knees, a strong relationship emerged suggesting that the shape of the femur can predict how much the knee bends.

                This relationship was then used to estimate the knee angles in fossil human ancestors. Miller compared these estimates to the range of knee angles seen in modern humans, which she calculated using walking data collected with a program called OpenCap. Some fossil species had knee angles similar to modern humans, but others bent their knees much more, suggesting that early human ancestors walked in different ways.

This project provided new insights into how upright walking evolved:

  • It identified specific features of the knee related to upright walking
  • It supported the idea that early human ancestors did not all walk like modern humans, with different species using different styles of walking
  • The femur was found to be a reliable indicator of knee function and movement, which will help researchers interpret new fossil finds

This study also contributed to our understanding of how living primates move, offering comparisons that help us interpret fossil evidence.

                This project gave Miller valuable experience. She worked with important fossil and primate skeletal collections at museums worldwide, learned advanced shape analysis techniques, and studied movement in both living primates and humans. She also developed skills in 3D scanning and analyzing joint motion. This research has already been presented at major conferences including the American Association of Biological Anthropologists and published in a journal. More papers are planned for open-access journals.

                In addition to her research, Miller shared her findings with the public and worked with undergraduate students. She gave lab tours, participated in events like Dartmouth’s Science Day, participated in the Skype a Scientist program, and appeared in a podcast interview. She also taught undergraduates how to use the 3D scanning technology during a paleoanthropology lab course, helping to train the next generation of researchers.

                Miller plans to continue exploring the data collected in this project. She will use virtual models of the fossils to study how muscles worked in their knees and perform more detailed studies of the tibia and kneecap. These future projects will build on the foundation laid by this research, deepening our understanding of how the knee works in humans and primates and how upright walking evolved.

                This study revealed important details about how upright walking evolved in our ancestors. It highlighted the diversity of walking styles used by early human ancestors and showed how the shape of the femur relates to movement. Beyond advancing this scientific field, this project provided Miller with new skills, supported student training, and brought scientific findings to a broader audience. These results will continue to guide future discoveries about our ancient human relatives and their unique ways of moving.
